title: Ticket #6960: shared port on Windows can make damons slow to notice signals
description:
When shared port is enabled on Windows, daemons can be slow to notice "signals" that are sent using the DC_RAISESIGNAL command.

The problem is that after the command handler for HandleSigCommand updates the daemon core signal table. the daemon core pump goes back into select, and only notices the pending signal in the table after select wakes again - usually after a timeout. For example 

StartLog fragment
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS) PERF: leaving select
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS) State = TIMED_OUT
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS) max_fd = 756
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS) Selection FD's
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS)        Read {756 } = 1
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS)        Write {} = 0
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS)        Except {} = 0
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS) Timeout = 1.000000 seconds
03/19/19 14:39:31.372 (D_ALWAYS) PERF: entering select. timeout=59
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS) PERF: leaving select
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS) State = FDS_READY
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS) max_fd = 756

03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS)        Write {} = 0
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS)        Except {} = 0
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS) Timeout = 59.000000 seconds
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_COMMAND) Calling HandleReq <HandleSigCommand()> (0) for command 60000 (DC_RAISESIGNAL) from ...
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_COMMAND) Return from HandleReq <HandleSigCommand()> ...
03/19/19 14:39:58.129 (D_ALWAYS) PERF: entering select. timeout=32
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS) PERF: leaving select
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS) State = TIMED_OUT
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS) max_fd = 756
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS) Selection FD's
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS)        Read {756 } = 1
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS)        Write {} = 0
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS)        Except {} = 0
03/19/19 14:40:30.129 (D_ALWAYS) Timeout = 32.000000 seconds
03/19/19 14:40:30.130 (D_ALWAYS) Calling Handler <handle_dc_sighup()> for Signal 1 <SIGHUP>
03/19/19 14:40:30.130 (D_ALWAYS) Got SIGHUP.  Re-reading config files.
03/19/19 14:40:30.248 (D_ALWAYS) History file rotation is enabled.
03/19/19 14:40:30.248 (D_ALWAYS)   Maximum history file size is: 20971520 bytes
03/19/19 14:40:30.248 (D_ALWAYS)   Number of rotated history files is: 2
03/19/19 14:40:31.097 (D_ALWAYS) PERF: entering select. timeout=3

Notice that HandleSigCommand is processed at 14:39:58.129, then select is entered and returns ~30 sec later at 14:40:30.129 having timed out. Only then does the pump notice the SIGHUP and does the reconfig.

Analysis

The problem is that when shared port is enabled, the DC_RAISESIGNAL command might be handled in SharedPortEndpoint::DoListenerAccept which is processed by DoPumpWork on Windows because the socket actually arrives via named pipe on a different thread.

DoPumpWork is processed with the timers, after the signal handlers and before select. If DoPumpWork were before the signal handlers, then there would not be this delay. Alternatively, if we forced the select timer to be 0 when the signal table is set, this would also avoid the delay.
remarks:
2019-Mar-20 12:15:44 by tlmiller:
Code Review

This looks good. There should be no further implications of moving the (Windows-specific) work pump in front of the signal handling, because Windows doesn't actually have signals. (It may be possible for the DC_RAISESIGNAL to be handled during normal socket-handling, depending on the security settings, if the work pump handles security but the command packet is delayed, but that's fine: select() will exit when the command packet arrives and the signal will be handled after pumping work on the next go-around.)

2019-Mar-20 12:16:52 by tlmiller:
This might be worth mentioning in the version history (and maybe to fill out a release announcement).
